question: What does assessing unit mean?
answer: Assessing unit means a city, town, or county with the power to assess real property, unless the city, town or county is part of a consolidated assessing unit; a consolidated assessing unit; or a village as provided in section fourteen hundred two of this chapter.

question: What does assessment mean?
answer: Assessment means a determination made by assessors of (1) the valuation of real property, including the valuation of exempt real property and (2) whether or not real property is subject to taxation or special ad valorem levies.

question: Who are assessors?
answer: Assessors mean an elected or appointed officer or body of officers charged by law with the duty of assessing real property in an assessing unit for the purposes of taxation or special ad valorem levies, for county, city, town, village, school district or special district purposes.

question: What is the board of assessment review?
answer: Board of assessment review means the body of officers constituted by subdivision one of section five hundred twenty-three of this chapter and, in the case of villages, by subdivision one of section fourteen hundred eight of this chapter which is empowered to hear and determine complaints in relation to assessments.

question: Who is the chief executive officer?
answer: Chief executive officer means (a) in the case of cities, the mayor, except in cities having a city manager in which case it shall mean the city manager, (b) in the case of villages, the mayor and (c) in the case of towns, the supervisor.

question: What is a collecting officer?
answer: Collecting officer means an elected or appointed officer of any municipal corporation or special district authorized by law to receive and collect taxes, special ad valorem levies or special assessments.

question: Who is the commissioner?
answer: Commissioner means the commissioner of taxation and finance.

question: What is the definition of comptroller?
answer: Comptroller means the state comptroller.

question: What does consolidated assessing unit mean?
answer: Consolidated assessing unit means an assessing unit established pursuant to article sixteen of this chapter.

question: What is a county equalization agency?
answer: County equalization agency means the board of supervisors, commissioners of equalization or other county agency authorized by this chapter or any other law to establish county equalization rates.

question: What does county equalization rate mean?
answer: County equalization rate means the percentage of full value at which taxable real property in a city or town is assessed as determined by a county equalization agency for purposes of apportioning county real property taxes.

question: Who is the county treasurer?
answer: County treasurer means the chief fiscal officer of a county charged by law with performing the duties of treasurer, by whatever name known or called.

question: What is the definition of infant or minor?
answer: Infant or minor means a person who has not attained the age of eighteen years.

question: What does department refer to?
answer: Department means the department of taxation and finance.

question: What is a municipal corporation?
answer: Municipal corporation means a county, city, town, village or school district.

question: What is the definition of a parcel?
answer: Parcel means a separately assessed lot, parcel, piece or portion of real property, except publicly owned bridges and land used for street, road, highway or parkway purposes. A parcel shall not be bisected by a municipal corporation boundary line except that in a special assessing unit a parcel may be bisected by a school district or village boundary line.

question: How is real property defined?
answer: Real property, property or land mean and include: (a) Land itself, above and under water, including trees and undergrowth thereon and mines, minerals, quarries and fossils in and under the same, except mines belonging to the state; (b) Buildings and other articles and structures, substructures and superstructures erected upon, under or above the land, or affixed thereto, including bridges and wharves and piers and the value of the right to collect wharfage, cranage or dockage thereon; (c) Surface, underground or elevated railroads, and railroad structures, substructures and superstructures, tracks and the metal thereon, branches, switches and other fixtures permitted or authorized to be made, laid or placed in, upon, above or under any public or private street or place.

question: What does the term real property include when owned by a telephone company?
answer: ll telephone and telegraph lines, wires, poles, supports, and enclosures for electrical conductors upon, above, and underground.

question: What does the term real property not include when owned by a telephone company?
answer: Station connections.

question: What does the term telephone company mean?
answer: company subject to regulation by the public service commission which provides non-cellular switched local exchange telephone service to the general public within its local exchange area.

question: What does the term real property include for conducting steam, heat, water, oil, electricity, or any property capable of transportation?
answer: Mains, pipes, and tanks permitted or authorized to be made, laid, or placed in, upon, above, or under any public or private street or place.

question: What does the term real property include for boilers, ventilating apparatus, elevators, plumbing, heating, lighting, and power generating apparatus?
answer: It includes all of the mentioned equipment except movable machinery or equipment owned by a corporation taxable under article nine-a of the tax law, used for trade or manufacture, and removable without material injury to the building or structure.

question: What does the term real property include for housing adaptable to power?
answer: It includes trailers or mobile homes that can be used for residential, business, commercial, or office purposes, except for those located within an assessing unit for less than sixty days, unoccupied and for sale, or recreational vehicles that are four hundred square feet or less in size and used as temporary living quarters for recreational, camping, travel, or seasonal use.

question: What happens to the value of a trailer or mobile home if it is entitled to an exemption?
answer: It shall be separately assessed in the name of the owner if either the trailer or mobile home or the land on which it is located is entitled to any exemption pursuant to article four of this chapter, other than the exemption authorized by section four hundred twenty-five of this chapter.

question: What are special franchises?
answer: Special franchises are defined as the franchise, right, authority, or permission to construct, maintain, or operate mains, pipes, tanks, conduits, wires, or transformers in public streets, highways, water, or other public places for conducting water, steam, light, power, electricity, gas, or other substances.

question: What does the term special franchise include for assessment and taxation purposes?
answer: It includes the value of the tangible property situated in, under, above, upon, or through any public street, highway, water, or other public place in connection with the special franchise.

question: What does the term special franchise not include?
answer: It does not include central office equipment or station equipment owned by a telephone company or telephone corporation, property of a municipal corporation, public benefit corporation or special district, or a crossing less than two hundred fifty feet in length of a public street, highway, water, or other public place outside a city or village, unless it is the continuation of an occupancy of another public street, highway, water, or other public place.

question: What is the definition of revaluation, reassessment, or update?
answer: It means a systematic review of the assessments of all locally assessed properties to attain compliance with the standard of assessment set forth in subdivision two of section three hundred five of this chapter.

question: What are school authorities?
answer: School authorities refer to the board of education, trustees, or corresponding officers of a school district.

question: What is a special ad valorem levy?
answer: It is a charge imposed upon benefited real property in the same manner and at the same time as taxes for municipal purposes to defray the cost, including operation and maintenance, of a special district improvement or service, excluding any charge imposed by or on behalf of a city or village.

question: What is a special assessment?
answer: It is a charge imposed upon benefited real property in proportion to the benefit received by such property to defray the cost, including operation and maintenance, of a special district improvement or service or a special improvement or service, but it does not include a special ad valorem levy.

question: What is a special district?
answer: It is a town or county improvement district, district corporation, or other district established for the purpose of carrying on, performing, or financing one or more improvements or services intended to benefit the health, welfare, safety, or convenience of the inhabitants of such district or to benefit the real property within such district.

question: What is a state equalization rate?
answer: It is the percentage of full value at which taxable real property in a county, city, town, or village is assessed as determined by the commissioner.

question: What is a tax or taxation?
answer: It is a charge imposed upon real property by or on behalf of a county, city, town, village, or school district for municipal or school district purposes, excluding a special ad valorem levy or a special assessment.

question: What is a tax lien?
answer: It is an unpaid tax, special ad valorem levy, special assessment, or other charge imposed upon real property by or on behalf of a municipal corporation or special district, which is an encumbrance on real property.

question: What is the purpose of electronic real property tax administration?
answer: The purpose is to establish standards for executing real property tax administration tasks electronically, eliminating the need for paper documents.

question: What tasks can be executed electronically under electronic real property tax administration?
answer: Tasks that can be executed electronically include filing exemption applications, filing petitions for administrative review of assessments, filing petitions for judicial review of assessments, filing applications for administrative corrections of errors, issuing statements of taxes, paying taxes, providing receipts for tax payments, issuing taxpayer notices required by law, and furnishing notices and certificates related to various aspects of real property tax administration.

question: What are the provisions of the general municipal law regarding the payment of taxes?
answer: The provisions of sections five and five-b of the general municipal law govern the payment of taxes.

question: What notices are required to be issued to taxpayers by law?
answer: Taxpayer notices required by law include those specified in sections five hundred eight, five hundred ten, five hundred ten-a, five hundred eleven, five hundred twenty-five, and five hundred fifty-one-a through five hundred fifty-six-b of this chapter.

question: What notices and certificates can be furnished under this chapter?
answer: Notices and certificates relating to state equalization rates, residential assessment ratios, special franchise assessments, railroad ceilings, taxable state lands, advisory appraisals, and the certification of assessors and county directors or real property tax services can be furnished under this chapter, subject to the provisions of subdivision five of this section.

question: Who shall be consulted in the development of standards?
answer: Local government officials, the office of court administration, and the office of the state comptroller.

question: Are taxpayers required to accept electronic communications?
answer: No, taxpayers are not required to accept electronic communications unless they have elected to do so.

question: How can a municipal corporation provide electronic real property tax administration?
answer: The governing board of a municipal corporation can determine that it is in the public interest to provide electronic real property tax administration through a local law, ordinance, or resolution.

question: What information can be collected from taxpayers who elect to receive electronic communications?
answer: The standards prescribed by the commissioner allow for the collection of electronic contact information, such as e-mail addresses andor social network usernames.

question: How is a document transmitted electronically considered?
answer: When a document is transmitted electronically in accordance with the provisions and standards set by the commissioner, it is deemed to satisfy the applicable legal requirements as if it had been mailed via the United States postal service.

question: How can the commissioner provide notice of a tentative determination?
answer: The commissioner can provide notice of a tentative determination by e-mail, by posting it on the department's website, or both.

question: What should be done if a complaint regarding a tentative determination is sent by e-mail?
answer: If a complaint is sent to the commissioner by e-mail to the specified e-mail address by the prescribed date, it is deemed valid as if it had been sent by postal mail.

question: How is notice of a final determination provided?
answer: Notice of a final determination can be provided by e-mail, by a website posting, or both, at the commissioner's discretion.

question: Can an assessor choose to receive notices by postal mail?
answer: Yes, if an assessor advises the commissioner in writing of their preference for postal mail, the notices will be sent to them by postal mail.

question: What happens if an invalid e-mail address is used for notice?
answer: If the commissioner learns that an e-mail address is not valid or cannot find a valid e-mail address, the notice will be resent by postal mail.

question: What is the definition of postal mail?
answer: Postal mail refers to mail that is physically delivered to the addressee by the United States postal service.

question: What is the purpose of the state board of real property tax services?
answer: The state board of real property tax services is created to provide separate and independent oversight of real property tax services.

question: How long is the initial term of the appointed individual?
answer: The initial term is eight years.

question: When does the initial term commence?
answer: The initial term commences on the first day of January next succeeding the year in which the existing term shall expire.

question: Who designates the chairman of the board?
answer: The governor designates the chairman of the board.

question: How long does the chairman serve as chairman?
answer: The chairman serves at the pleasure of the governor.

question: How many members constitute a quorum?
answer: majority of the duly appointed members constitute a quorum.

question: What can a majority of the members do?
answer: majority of the members can transact any business, perform any duty, or exercise any power of the board.

question: How long are the members of the board appointed for?
answer: The members of the board are appointed for terms of eight years.

question: When do the terms of the members first appointed expire?
answer: The terms of the members first appointed expire on specific dates, such as December thirty-first, nineteen hundred sixty-one.

question: How are vacancies filled?
answer: Vacancies occurring otherwise than by expiration of term are filled for the unexpired term.

question: What expenses do all members receive?
answer: ll members receive necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties.

question: What are the powers, functions, duties, and obligations of the state board of real property tax services?
answer: The powers, functions, duties, and obligations of the state board of real property tax services are separate from and independent of the authority of the department of taxation and finance. The board is empowered to adopt guidelines for effective decision-making.

question: What powers does the state board of real property tax services have in relation to real property tax administration?
answer: The board has the power to determine the final special franchise value, special franchise assessment, railroad ceiling, state equalization rate, or any other equalization product established under this chapter when a complaint has been filed.

question: Which sections of the chapter provide the authority for the state board of real property tax services to determine the final values and assessments?
answer: The sections that provide the authority for the state board of real property tax services to determine the final values and assessments are four hundred eighty-nine-o, four hundred eighty-nine-ll, four hundred ninety-nine-pppp, six hundred fourteen, twelve hundred ten, twelve hundred fifty-three, and twelve hundred sixty-three.

question: When does the effective date of the powers mentioned in the previous question expire?
answer: The effective date of these powers expires on January 1, 2027.

question: What are the functions, powers, and duties of the state board of real property services?
answer: The functions, powers, and duties of the state board of real property services are considered to be functions, powers, and duties of the commissioner of taxation and finance.

question: When did this change in responsibilities take effect?
answer: This change in responsibilities took effect on the effective date of this section.

question: What is the effective date of this section?
answer: The effective date of this section is January 1, 2027.

question: What reviews can the board of real property tax services hear and determine?
answer: The board of real property tax services can hear and determine reviews relating to determinations made by county equalization agencies and reviews relating to determinations of STAR eligibility made by the department of taxation and finance.

question: What sections of the chapter provide the power to hear and determine reviews for county equalization agencies?
answer: The power to hear and determine reviews for county equalization agencies is provided by sections eight hundred sixteen and eight hundred eighteen of this chapter.

question: What section of the chapter provides the power to hear and determine reviews for determinations of STAR eligibility?
answer: The power to hear and determine reviews for determinations of STAR eligibility is provided by section four hundred twenty five of this chapter.

question: Which section of the chapter applies to a hearing conducted by the board of real property tax services?
answer: The provisions of section five hundred twenty-five of this chapter apply to a hearing conducted by the board of real property tax services pursuant to this chapter.

question: What functions, powers, and duties are considered functions of the commissioner of taxation and finance?
answer: The functions, powers, and duties of the office of real property services.

question: What happens to the employees of the office of real property services when the functions are transferred to the department of taxation and finance?
answer: They shall be transferred to the department without further examination or qualification.

question: Will the employees retain their civil service classifications, status, and collective bargaining agreements?
answer: Yes, they will retain their respective civil service classifications, status, and collective bargaining unit designations and collective bargaining agreements.

question: Who will receive the books, papers, and property of the office of real property services?
answer: The commissioner of taxation and finance.

question: Who will maintain the books, papers, and property of the office of real property services?
answer: The department of taxation and finance.

question: What obligations are transferred and assigned to the department?
answer: The obligations transferred and assigned to the department are those outlined in this section.

question: What is the department deemed to constitute?
answer: The department is deemed to constitute the continuation of the office of real property services.

question: Can the commissioner or the department conduct and complete any pending business or matter?
answer: Yes, the commissioner or the department can conduct and complete any pending business or matter pertaining to the transferred functions, powers, obligations, and duties.

question: How should the commissioner or the department conduct and complete the pending business or matter?
answer: The commissioner or the department should conduct and complete the pending business or matter in the same manner and under the same terms and conditions as the state board of real property services or the office of real property services.

question: What happens to the rules, regulations, acts, orders, determinations, and decisions of the state board of real property services or the office of real property services?
answer: ll rules, regulations, acts, orders, determinations, and decisions of the state board of real property services or the office of real property services continue in full force and effect as rules, regulations, acts, orders, determinations, and decisions of the department until modified or abrogated by the commissioner or the department.

question: What acts, orders, determinations, and decisions of the state board of real property services will continue in full force and effect?
answer: ll acts, orders, determinations, and decisions of the state board of real property services pertaining to the functions and powers provided in section two hundred-a of this article will continue in full force and effect as acts, orders, determinations, and decisions of the state board of real property tax services.

question: Who will the state board of real property services, the office of real property services, or its executive director be referred to or designated as in any law, contract, or document pertaining to the transferred functions, powers, obligations, and duties?
answer: The state board of real property services, the office of real property services, or its executive director will be referred to or designated as the commissioner or the department, as applicable or indicated by the context.

question: Will any existing right or remedy be lost, impaired, or affected by any provisions of this section?
answer: No, no existing right or remedy of any character shall be lost, impaired, or affected by any provisions of this section.

question: Will any action or proceeding pending on the effective date of this section, brought by or against the state board of real property services, the office of real property services, or its executive director be affected by any provision of this section?
answer: No, no action or proceeding pending on the effective date of this section, brought by or against the state board of real property services, the office of real property services, or its executive director shall be affected by any provision of this section. They may be prosecuted or defended in the name of the commissioner or the department.

question: What happens to the appropriations or reappropriations made to the office of real property services?
answer: They are transferred to and made available for use and expenditure by the department, subject to the approval of the director of the budget.

question: Who is responsible for certifying or approving vouchers for payment?
answer: The commissioner is responsible for certifying or approving vouchers for payment.

question: What happens to the assets and liabilities of the office of real property services?
answer: They are transferred to and assumed by the department.

question: What powers and duties does the commissioner have in relation to real property tax administration?
answer: The commissioner has the power and duty to assess special franchises, establish state equalization rates, approve assessments of state lands subject to taxation, and have general supervision of the function of assessing throughout the state.

question: What is the purpose of investigating the methods of assessment throughout the state?
answer: The purpose is to gather information and understand the different methods of assessment used.

question: Who does the commissioner confer with, advise, and assist?
answer: The commissioner confers with, advises, and assists assessors and other officials whose duties relate to assessments.

question: What kind of information and instructions does the commissioner furnish assessors with?
answer: The commissioner furnishes assessors with information and instructions necessary to aid them in making assessments.

question: How are the instructions provided by the commissioner enforced?
answer: The instructions provided by the commissioner are followed and compliance with them may be enforced.

question: What forms does the commissioner prescribe and furnish to assessors?
answer: The commissioner prescribes and furnishes forms relating to assessments, including applications for exemption from real property taxation.

question: Who is required to use the forms prescribed by the commissioner?
answer: The assessors and applicants for an exemption granted pursuant to this or any other chapter are required to use the forms prescribed by the commissioner.

question: How does the commissioner obtain necessary information for the discharge of their duties?
answer: The commissioner obtains necessary information from state and local officers, bodies, or other agencies upon demand.

question: What does the commissioner do regarding the laws of other states?
answer: The commissioner inquires into the provisions of the laws of other states and confers with the appropriate officials regarding the most effectual methods.

question: What are some methods of assessing and taxing real property?
answer: Equitable methods of assessing and taxing real property.

question: What is included in the annual report prepared by the legislature?
answer: The annual report includes recommendations for amendments to existing law and other advisable information.

question: What powers does the individual have to adopt rules and regulations?
answer: The individual has the power to adopt and amend rules, regulations, orders, and determinations necessary for their duties.

question: What is the purpose of establishing railroad ceilings for railroad real property?
answer: The purpose is to establish limits on the assessment of railroad real property.

question: What other powers and duties can be conferred or imposed on the individual?
answer: The individual can exercise and perform any other powers and duties imposed by law.

question: What is the role of the individual in monitoring local assessment practices?
answer: The individual is responsible for monitoring the quality of local assessment practices by individual assessing units.

question: What charges or fees can the individual impose, collect, and receive?
answer: The individual can impose, collect, and receive charges or fees authorized by statute.

question: What is the purpose of promulgating rules and regulations for assessment record billing owner information?
answer: The purpose is to administer the eminent domain procedure law by ascertaining and reporting assessment record billing owner information.

question: What actions can an assessing unit take?
answer: n assessing unit can act pursuant to certain instances.

question: What actions can the commissioner take if their rules or regulations are subject to judicial review?
answer: The commissioner may assist the assessing unit by filing a brief amicus curiae or using other appropriate means.

question: What can the commissioner do to implement the computerized statewide school district address match and income verification system?
answer: The commissioner can adopt necessary rules and regulations.

question: Are the records that come into the commissioner's custody accessible to the public?
answer: Yes, the records are subject to public access to the full extent provided by this chapter and the public officers law.

question: What powers and duties does the commissioner have in relation to real property tax administration?
answer: The commissioner can assess special franchises and establish state equalization rates for each county, city, town, and village.

question: What is the role of the commissioner in relation to state lands subject to taxation?
answer: The commissioner approves assessments of state lands subject to taxation.

question: What is the general supervision function of the commissioner?
answer: The commissioner has general supervision of the function of assessing throughout the state.

question: What does the commissioner do in relation to the methods of assessment throughout the state?
answer: The commissioner investigates the methods of assessment throughout the state from time to time.

question: Who does the commissioner confer with, advise, and assist in relation to assessments?
answer: The commissioner confers with, advises, and assists assessors and other officials whose duties relate to assessments.

question: What does the commissioner do to aid assessors in making assessments?
answer: The commissioner furnishes assessors with necessary information and instructions to aid them in making assessments.

question: What forms does the commissioner prescribe and furnish to assessors?
answer: The commissioner prescribes and furnishes forms relating to assessments, including applications for exemption from real property taxation.

question: How does the commissioner enforce the use of prescribed forms by assessors?
answer: The commissioner enforces the use of prescribed forms by assessors.

question: What information does the commissioner obtain from state and local officers, bodies, or other agencies?
answer: The commissioner obtains necessary information for the proper discharge of duties in relation to real property tax administration.

question: What is the purpose of inquiring into the provisions of the laws of other states?
answer: The purpose is to confer with the appropriate officials regarding the most effectual and equitable methods of assessing and taxing real property.

question: What is included in the annual report to the legislature?
answer: The annual report includes recommendations concerning amendments to existing law and any other information deemed advisable.

question: What authority does the individual have to adopt and amend rules, regulations, orders, and determinations?
answer: The individual has the authority to adopt and amend such rules, regulations, orders, and determinations as necessary for the exercise of their powers and duties under this chapter, as long as they are not inconsistent with the law.

question: What is the purpose of establishing railroad ceilings for railroad real property?
answer: The purpose is to set limits on the assessment of railroad real property.

question: What other powers and duties may be conferred or imposed on the individual by law?
answer: The individual may be conferred or imposed with any other powers and duties as determined by law.

question: What is the purpose of monitoring the quality of local assessment practices?
answer: The purpose is to ensure the quality of assessment practices by individual assessing units.

question: What charges or fees can the individual impose, collect, and receive?
answer: The individual can impose, collect, and receive charges or fees as authorized by statute.

question: What is the purpose of promulgating rules and regulations for the ascertainment and reporting of assessment record billing owner information?
answer: The purpose is to establish guidelines for determining and reporting information related to assessment record billing owner.

question: What is the purpose of section one hundred three of the eminent domain procedure law?
answer: The purpose of section one hundred three of the eminent domain procedure law is for the administration of such law.

question: What can the commissioner do if an assessing unit has acted pursuant to their instructions and it becomes the subject of a judicial review?
answer: The commissioner can assist the assessing unit by filing a brief amicus curiae or through other appropriate means upon request.

question: What authority does the commissioner have to adopt rules and regulations?
answer: The commissioner has the authority to adopt rules and regulations necessary to implement the computerized statewide school district address match and income verification system.

question: Are records that come into the commissioner's custody subject to public access?
answer: Yes, records that come into the commissioner's custody are subject to public access to the full extent provided by this chapter and the public officers law.

question: Are the secrecy provisions of the tax law applicable to records in the commissioner's custody?
answer: No, the secrecy provisions of the tax law do not apply to records in the commissioner's custody.

question: What is the purpose of the Office of Real Property Tax Services?
answer: The purpose of the Office of Real Property Tax Services is to administer real property tax administration.

question: Who is the head of the Office of Real Property Tax Services?
answer: The head of the Office of Real Property Tax Services is the deputy commissioner for real property tax services.

question: What is the role of the deputy commissioner for real property tax services?
answer: The deputy commissioner for real property tax services exercises powers and duties in relation to real property tax administration and serves as the executive officer and secretary of the state board of real property tax services.

question: How is the deputy commissioner for real property tax services appointed?
answer: The deputy commissioner for real property tax services is appointed by the governor.

question: Who does the deputy commissioner for real property tax services report to?
answer: The deputy commissioner for real property tax services reports directly to the commissioner.

question: Can the commissioner appoint additional officers, employees, agents, consultants, and special committees?
answer: Yes, the commissioner may appoint such individuals as deemed necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter and prescribe their duties.

question: What powers do members of the board and authorized officers or employees have?
answer: Members of the board and authorized officers or employees have the power to administer oaths, take affidavits, and certify acknowledgements.

question: How are members of the state board of real property tax services authorized?
answer: Members of the state board of real property tax services are duly authorized by resolution of the board.

question: What powers does the board have under this chapter?
answer: The board has the power to subpoena witnesses and require the production of documents.

question: Who can be subpoenaed by the board?
answer: Witnesses can be subpoenaed by the board.

question: What can the board examine witnesses in relation to?
answer: The board can examine witnesses in relation to any matter it has the power to investigate.

question: Can the board issue commissions for the examination of out-of-state witnesses?
answer: Yes, the board can issue commissions for the examination of witnesses who are out of the state.

question: How is a subpoena issued under this section regulated?
answer: subpoena issued under this section is regulated by the civil practice law and rules.

question: How should an instrument be executed by the board?
answer: n instrument should be executed by affixing the name of the board and the signature of one or more of its members or designated officersemployees.

question: Is an acknowledgment of the execution of an instrument necessary for recordation?
answer: No, an acknowledgment of the execution of an instrument is not necessary for recordation.

question: What does the board have?
answer: The board has an official seal.

question: How can the records and documents of the board be authenticated?
answer: The records, proceedings, and copies of all papers and documents in the board's possession and custody can be authenticated in the usual form, under the official seal and the signature of any member of the board or designated officer or employee of the state board of real property tax services.

question: How will the authenticated records and documents be treated as evidence?
answer: The authenticated records and documents will be received in evidence in the same manner and with like effect as deeds regularly acknowledged or proven.

question: What powers does the commissioner have in case of neglect or refusal of officials to perform duties?
answer: The commissioner has powers to take action when it is determined that any assessor or other public officer, employee, or board of assessment review has failed to comply with the provisions of the law or rules and regulations related to real property tax administration.

question: What can the commissioner do if an official fails to comply with the law or regulations?
answer: fter a hearing on the facts, the commissioner may issue an order directing the non-compliant assessor, officer, employee, or board of assessment review to comply with the law, rule, or regulation.

question: What happens if an assessor or public officer refuses to perform their duties related to real property tax administration?
answer: They shall forfeit a sum not to exceed fifty dollars for each willful and intentional violation to the municipal corporation.

question: Who can recover the forfeited sum from the assessor or public officer?
answer: The commissioner can recover the forfeited sum.

question: What happens if a property owner is directly affected by a violation of state law or rule?
answer: The commissioner shall establish procedures for the assessor, officer, employee, or board of assessment review to remedy the failure to comply with the law or rules.

question: Can the assessor, officer, employee, or board of assessment review remedy the failure to comply with the law or rules?
answer: Yes, they can remedy the failure to comply.

question: What actions can be taken as a remedy for the failure to comply with the law or rules?
answer: The remedy may include reconvening the board of assessment review, identifying eligible complainants, and issuing instructions to the board.

question: What is the purpose of the assessment review?
answer: The purpose of the assessment review is to evaluate the law and any required documentation of eligible complainants in relation to the findings of the commissioner.

question: Who receives a copy of the order regarding the assessment review?
answer: The assessor, officer, employee, board of assessment review, and each municipal corporation utilizing the assessment roll receive a copy of the order.

question: What does the order require the assessing unit to do?
answer: The order requires the assessing unit to mail a copy of the order to each eligible complainant whose name and address can be easily determined from the record of the proceeding.

question: What happens when the commissioner orders the board of assessment review to reconvene?
answer: When the commissioner orders the board of assessment review to reconvene, a copy of the order is mailed to each eligible complainant along with a prescribed form for complaints on tentative assessments or any other form designated for that purpose.

question: What information is included with the order and form sent to eligible complainants?
answer: The order and form sent to eligible complainants include a notice stating the date, time, and place at which the board of assessment review will reconvene.

question: When should the material be mailed to the eligible complainant?

question: What powers and authority does the board of assessment review have during the reconvened meeting?

question: Can a petition for review of the assessment of a property be filed?

question: What should the assessor do upon receipt of the verified statement of changes from the board of assessment review?

question: What should the assessor do if they no longer have custody of the assessment roll when the verified statement is received?

question: What happens if a refund is not made within ninety days?

question: What is the definition of a UDC Large Scale Project?
answer: UDC Large Scale Project is a multi-phase project that includes the development of at least twenty-five hundred new dwelling units, is being implemented pursuant to a General Project Plan adopted by the New York State Urban Development Corporation and approved by Public Authorities Control Board, or is otherwise set forth in agreements with the New York State Urban Development Corporation. It also includes a development over a single area containing a number of contiguous city blocks, and the units in which, in the aggregate for each successive fifteen hundred units of the project rather than for each multiple dwelling containing such fifteen hundred units and in the aggregate for the entire project rather than for each multiple dwelling in the project, meet the requirements of paragraph (c) of subdivision seven of this section.

question: What is the exemption cap provided in local law for the agreement with the local housing agency?
answer: The exemption cap provided in local law for the agreement with the local housing agency is seven or nine of this section.

question: What are the conditions for the agreement with the local housing agency to be valid?
answer: The agreement with the local housing agency must have been entered into prior to December twenty-eighth, two thousand six, and construction of the building receiving benefits pursuant to this section must be commenced on or before June thirtieth, two thousand nine.

question: Are there any exceptions to the exemption cap provided in local law?
answer: Yes, there is an exception for UDC Large Scale Projects.

question: What are the requirements for tax benefits for a multiple dwelling in a UDC Large Scale Project?

question: How long is the period of tax benefits awarded to a multiple dwelling that meets the requirements?
answer: The period of tax benefits awarded to a multiple dwelling that meets the requirements is the same as the period of tax benefits awarded under clause (A) of subparagraph (iii) of paragraph (a) of subdivision two of this section.

question: How long is the period of tax benefits awarded to a multiple dwelling that does not meet the requirements?
answer: The period of tax benefits awarded to a multiple dwelling that does not meet the requirements is the same as the period of tax benefits awarded under clause (A) of subparagraph (ii) of paragraph (a) of subdivision two of this section.

question: When do the tax benefits awarded to a multiple dwelling in a UDC Large Scale Project commence?
answer: The tax benefits awarded to a multiple dwelling in a UDC Large Scale Project commence upon the commencement of construction of such multiple dwelling, provided that it meets all the requirements for tax benefits pursuant to this section.

question: What must the local housing agency certify for each successive fifteen hundred units of a UDC Large Scale Project?

question: When are the determinations based on ownership as of the thirty-first day of December of the second year preceding the date required by law?
answer: The determinations based on ownership as of the thirty-first day of December of the second year preceding the date required by law apply to the filing of the final assessment roll for purposes of city assessment rolls required to be filed between January first and June first inclusive and for all village assessment rolls.

question: What does the term rate valuation date mean?
answer: The term rate valuation date refers to the date as of which the full value of taxable real property on an assessment roll is estimated for purposes of the state equalization rate to be applied in the establishment of the railroad.

question: What is the purpose of determining the railroad ceiling?
answer: The purpose is to determine the extent to which railroad real property shall be exempt under this title.

question: Who establishes the railroad ceiling?
answer: The commissioner establishes the railroad ceiling annually.

question: How is the system reproduction cost determined?
answer: The system reproduction cost is determined in accordance with the provisions of sections four hundred eighty-nine-f and four hundred eighty-nine-g of this chapter.

question: How are the average railway earnings determined?
answer: The average railway earnings are determined in accordance with the provisions of sections four hundred eighty-nine-f and four hundred eighty-nine-h of this chapter.

question: What is the earnings ratio used for?
answer: The earnings ratio is used in accordance with the provisions of section four hundred eighty-nine-i of this chapter.

question: What is the exemption factor used for?
answer: The exemption factor is used in accordance with the provisions of section four hundred eighty-nine-j of this chapter.

question: How is the local reproduction cost determined?
answer: The local reproduction cost is determined in accordance with the provisions of sections four hundred eighty-nine-f and four hundred eighty-nine-k of this chapter.

question: What is the formula for calculating the railroad ceiling?
answer: Multiply the local reproduction cost by the exemption factor.

question: What is the purpose of subtracting the result from the local reproduction cost?
answer: The purpose is to calculate the railroad ceiling.

question: How is the railroad ceiling calculated?
answer: The railroad ceiling is calculated by subtracting the result from the local reproduction cost and then multiplying it by the state equalization rate.

question: What determinations are made pursuant to this section?
answer: The determinations made pursuant to this section are based on the value of the railroad real property and ownership of such property.

question: When are the determinations based on ownership made?
answer: The determinations based on ownership are made as of the thirty-first day of December of the year preceding the year in which the assessment roll is filed.

question: What is the rate valuation date?
answer: The rate valuation date is the date as of which the full value of taxable real property is estimated for the state equalization rate.

question: When are the determinations based on ownership made for city assessment rolls?
answer: The determinations based on ownership are made as of the thirty-first day of December of the second year preceding the date required for filing the final assessment roll for city assessment rolls filed between January first and June first inclusive.

question: What is the definition of the term rate valuation date?
answer: The term rate valuation date refers to the date as of which the full value of taxable real property is estimated for the state equalization rate in the establishment of the railroad ceiling.

question: What is the purpose of establishing relationships among elements used in computation of railroad ceiling?
answer: The purpose is to ensure that the amount of exemptions from real property taxation granted to railroads is related to their individual rates of earnings.

question: Who is responsible for establishing and maintaining these relationships?
answer: The commissioner is responsible for establishing and maintaining these relationships.

question: What factors are considered in the computation of railroad ceiling?
answer: The factors considered are system reproduction cost, railway earnings, local reproduction cost, and state equalization rates.

question: How should system reproduction cost, local reproduction cost, and state equalization rates be based?
answer: They should be based, as far as practicable, upon the same period price levels.

question: What does system reproduction cost include?
answer: System reproduction cost includes, as far as practicable, the property constituting the railroad system from which the railway earnings were derived for the latest year included in the average railway earnings.

question: What should the aggregate of the local reproduction cost of each railroad company approximate?
answer: The aggregate of the local reproduction cost of each railroad company should approximate the amount included in the system reproduction cost of such railroad company on account of the property included in such local reproduction costs, as far as practicable.

question: What is the system reproduction cost?
answer: The system reproduction cost refers to the cost of reproducing the entire railroad system, including the road, equipment, land, rights, and working capital.

question: How is the system reproduction cost determined for each railroad company?
answer: The system reproduction cost is determined by ascertaining the cost of reproducing the road and equipment, the value of land and rights, and the working capital of each railroad company.

question: What factors are considered in determining the system reproduction cost?
answer: The factors considered in determining the system reproduction cost include the cost of reproduction new less depreciation of road and equipment, the value of land and rights, and the working capital including material and supplies.

question: What happens if a railroad company's property and management are located outside of the United States?
answer: If the major portion of a railroad company's property and management are located outside of the United States, the system reproduction cost will only include the property located within the United States.

question: How does the commissioner classify the property of each railroad company?
answer: The commissioner classifies the property of each railroad company as either transportation or non-transportation, to the extent practicable.

question: What is considered when ascertaining depreciation of property under this section?
answer: Depreciation of property is ascertained under this section by considering the decrease in value over time due to wear and tear or obsolescence.

question: What factors are considered in determining the value of property used in common carrier service?
answer: Consideration may be given to physical condition, average service lives of groups of property, and other factors, excluding earnings.

question: How is the value of land defined in this section?
answer: The value of land refers to the value of similar land in the immediate vicinity used for purposes other than railroad transportation.

question: What does the term value of rights in land in, above and under any public street, highway or parkway mean?
answer: It means ten percent of the value of land in the immediate vicinity used for purposes other than railroad transportation.

question: What publication does the commissioner consider when making determinations under this section?
answer: The commissioner considers the information contained in the publication entitled Elements of Value of Property Used in Common Carrier Service issued or made available by the bureau of accounts, cost finding, and valuation of the interstate commerce commission.

question: Can the commissioner consider information from other sources besides the publication mentioned?
answer: Yes, the commissioner may consider information available from the commissioner of transportation or other regulatory agency having jurisdiction over the property of the railroad company, as well as information available from other sources, including reports required pursuant to section four hundred eighty-nine-q, and any other information on the subject that may be available.

question: What is the allowance for grading in determining a system reproduction cost for railroad ceilings?
answer: The allowance for grading in place is eighteen percent per annum but shall not exceed ninety percent.

question: What factor should not be included in the calculation of system reproduction cost for railroad ceilings?
answer: The commissioner should not include a factor for any construction overhead in its calculation.

question: When should overhead costs not be included for new construction?
answer: Overhead costs should not be included for any new construction begun on or after the effective date of this subdivision.

question: How much should depreciation be increased for high speedhigh tonnage track and medium speedhigh tonnage track?
answer: Depreciation should be increased to seventy-five percent for high speedhigh tonnage track and medium speedhigh tonnage track.

question: How much should depreciation be increased for low speedmedium tonnage track?
answer: Depreciation should be increased to eighty-five percent for low speedmedium tonnage track.

question: How much should depreciation be increased for low speedlow tonnage track?
answer: Depreciation should be increased for low speedlow tonnage track.

question: What is the purpose of increasing depreciation to ninety percent?
answer: The purpose is to grant increased depreciation for railroad ceilings established for assessment rolls filed in two thousand four and thereafter.

question: Who is eligible to receive the increased depreciation?
answer: Railroad companies are eligible to receive the increased depreciation.

question: How long does the grant of increased depreciation continue?
answer: The grant of increased depreciation continues for ten years.

question: Can the grant of increased depreciation be approved for subsequent periods?
answer: Yes, the grant of increased depreciation can be approved for subsequent periods of ten years upon application and compliance with the standards established by rule and regulation.

question: Who establishes the schedules for increased depreciation and the standards for improved service?
answer: The commissioner, in consultation with the department of transportation and the division of the budget, establishes the schedules for increased depreciation and the standards for improved service.

question: What happens if a railroad company fails to file an application or meet the standards for improved services?
answer: If a railroad company fails to file an application or meet the standards for improved services, they will not receive the increased depreciation for railroad ceilings established for assessment rolls filed in two thousand four and thereafter.

question: What is the benefit for increased depreciation that a company would receive?
answer: The benefit for increased depreciation is one-half of what the company would have received if they had made the application and met the standards in a timely fashion.

question: What are the standards for increased depreciation based upon?
answer: The standards for increased depreciation may be based upon increased tonnage, increased level of passenger service, increased number of passenger trains, improved on-time performance, increased average speed, and any other factors indicating improved rail service as specified by the commissioner and the department of transportation.

question: How is the system reproduction cost of each railroad company determined?
answer: The system reproduction cost of each railroad company is determined by ascertaining the cost of reproduction new less depreciation of road and equipment, the value of land and rights, including rights in land above and under public streets, highways, or parkways, and the working capital including material and supplies.

question: What is included in the working capital for determining the system reproduction cost?
answer: The working capital includes material and supplies.

question: What happens if the property and management of a railroad company are located outside the territorial limits?
answer: If the property and management of a railroad company are located outside the territorial limits, it is not specified what happens in this scenario.

question: What does the system reproduction cost of a railroad company consist of?
answer: The system reproduction cost of a railroad company consists of the property located within the United States.

question: How does the commissioner classify the property of each railroad company?
answer: The commissioner classifies the property of each railroad company as transportation or non-transportation, as far as practicable.

question: What factors are considered when ascertaining depreciation of property under this section?

question: How is the term value of land defined in this section?
answer: In this section, the term value of land refers to the value of similar land in the immediate vicinity used for purposes other than railroad transportation.

question: What does the term value of rights in land in, above and under any public street, highway or parkway mean?
answer: The term value of rights in land in, above and under any public street, highway or parkway means ten percent of the value of land in the immediate vicinity used for purposes other than railroad transportation.

question: What information does the commissioner consider when making determinations under this section?

question: Who issued or made available the information mentioned in the text?

question: What other regulatory agency's information may the commissioner consider?
answer: The commissioner may consider information available from the commissioner of transportation or other regulatory agency having jurisdiction over the property of the railroad company.

question: What reports are required pursuant to section four hundred eighty-nine-q?
answer: The text does not specify what reports are required pursuant to section four hundred eighty-nine-q.

question: What is the depreciable asset deemed in determining a system reproduction cost for railroad ceilings?
answer: Grading is deemed a depreciable asset.

question: What factor should not be included in the calculation of system reproduction cost?
answer: Construction overhead should not be included in the calculation.

question: Are overhead costs included for new construction begun after a certain date?
answer: No, overhead costs should not be included for any new construction begun on or after the effective date of this subdivision.

question: What is the purpose of the railroad ceilings established for assessment rolls?

question: How much is the depreciation increased for high speedhigh tonnage track and medium speedhigh tonnage track?
answer: The depreciation is increased to seventy-five percent.

question: What are the regulations for increased depreciation and standards for improved service for railroads?

question: What are some of the factors that the commissioner and the department of transportation consider when determining the standards for increased depreciation?
answer: The factors considered for increased depreciation include increased tonnage, increased level of passenger service, increased number of passenger trains, improved on-time performance, increased average speed, and any other factors indicating improved rail service.

question: How are the average railway earnings determined for each railroad company?
answer: The average railway earnings are determined by ascertaining the revenues of each railroad company to the extent practicable.

question: What is a railroad company entitled to receive?
answer: railroad company is entitled to receive transportation service and rents from property constituting the railroad system included in the system reproduction cost.

question: What expenses should be ascertained in furnishing transportation service?
answer: The expenses incurred in furnishing transportation service include expenses incurred in the operation and maintenance of the property constituting the railroad system included in the system reproduction cost, depreciation of such property, rents, and other expenses incurred for property used by the railroad company for transportation purposes not included in the system reproduction cost, and United States government taxes for old-age retirement and unemployment insurance under the federal railroad retirement tax act and federal railroad unemployment insurance act.

question: How can railway earnings be calculated?
answer: Railway earnings can be calculated by subtracting the expenses from the revenues.

question: What should be done with the railway earnings?
answer: The railway earnings should be averaged for the latest five calendar years available prior to the tentative determination of the railroad ceiling.

question: What information should the commissioner consider in making determinations under this section?
answer: The commissioner should consider the information contained in the income, profit, and loss.

question: What financial statements are filed with the interstate commerce commission?
answer: The statements and other financial statements of the railroad company.

question: What accounting records are maintained by the railroad company?
answer: The accounting records maintained by the railroad company in accordance with the uniform system of accounts for railroad companies prescribed by the interstate commerce commission.

question: What information may the commissioner consider from other sources?

question: How does the commissioner determine the earnings ratio for each railroad company?
answer: The commissioner determines the earnings ratio for each railroad company by ascertaining the ratio of its average railway earnings to its system reproduction cost, computed to the nearest hundredth of one per cent.

question: How is the exemption factor for each railroad company determined?
answer: The exemption factor for each railroad company is determined in accordance with its earnings ratio, in accordance with the policy of granting increasingly greater exemptions as the rate of earnings of a railroad company declines.

question: What is the purpose of the table mentioned in the text?
answer: The purpose of the table is to determine the exemption factor for railroad companies based on their earnings ratio.

question: How is the exemption factor determined for a railroad company?
answer: The exemption factor for a railroad company is determined by finding the percentage indicated under the exemption factor column in the table that corresponds to the company's earnings ratio.

question: What happens if a railroad company's earnings ratio does not match any specific ratio in the table?
answer: If a railroad company's earnings ratio does not match any specific ratio in the table, the exemption factor for that company is determined through interpolation to the nearest tenth of one percent.

question: What is the unadjusted local reproduction cost for each railroad company in each assessing unit?
answer: The unadjusted local reproduction cost is determined by ascertaining the cost of reproduction new less depreciation of the railroad real property other than land and the value of the land portion of railroad real property and the value of rights in land in, above and under any public street, highway or parkway used by such railroad company.

question: How is the unadjusted local reproduction cost determined?
answer: The unadjusted local reproduction cost is determined by ascertaining the cost of reproduction new less depreciation of the railroad real property other than land and the value of the land portion of railroad real property and the value of rights in land in, above and under any public street, highway or parkway used by such railroad company.

question: What factors are considered in determining the unadjusted local reproduction cost?
answer: The factors considered in determining the unadjusted local reproduction cost are the cost of reproduction new less depreciation of the railroad real property other than land and the value of the land portion of railroad real property and the value of rights in land in, above and under any public street, highway or parkway used by such railroad company.

question: Is there a limit to the decrease in the exemption factor?
answer: Yes, there is a limit to the decrease in the exemption factor. It may not exceed one-tenth if it appears that the exemption factor is decreasing more than one-tenth from the exemption factor established in the prior year.

question: What is the result of adding the amounts ascertained under (a) and (b) for each assessing unit?
answer: The result is the unadjusted local reproduction cost.

question: How does the commissioner determine the local reproduction cost for each railroad company in each assessing unit?
answer: The commissioner computes the ratio of the total amount included in the system reproduction cost of the railroad company to the aggregate of the unadjusted local reproduction costs for all assessing units. Then, the commissioner multiplies the unadjusted local reproduction cost for each assessing unit by the computed ratio to determine the local reproduction cost.

question: What classification does the commissioner make for the real property of each railroad company?
answer: The commissioner classifies the real property of each railroad company as either transportation or non-transportation, to the extent practicable.

question: What factors are considered in ascertaining depreciation of property under this section?

answer: The value of land refers to the value of similar land in the immediate vicinity used for purposes other than railroad transportation.

answer: The term value of rights in land in, above and under any public street, highway or parkway means ten per cent of the value of land in the immediate vicinity used for purposes other than railroad transportation.

question: What time period should the determinations made under this section reflect?
answer: The determinations made under this section should reflect the status of the property as of December thirty-first of the preceding year.

question: What information should the commissioner consider when making determinations under this section?
answer: The commissioner should consider the information contained in accounts maintained pursuant to the uniform system of accounts for railroad companies prescribed by the interstate commerce commission. They should also consider the information in the publication entitled Elements of Value or Property Used in Common Carrier Service then most recently issued or made available by the bureau of accounts, cost finding, and valuation of the interstate commerce commission. Additionally, the commissioner may consider information available from the commissioner of transportation and other sources, including reports required pursuant to section four hundred eighty-nine-q, and any other information on the subject that may be available.

question: What is the state equalization rate used for?
answer: The state equalization rate is used in determining railroad ceilings.

question: When is a special equalization rate applied?
answer: special equalization rate is applied if it has been established or if there has been a change in the level of assessment on the assessment roll.

question: How is the equalization rate computed for railroad ceilings in the city of New York?
answer: The equalization rate is computed by the commissioner on a city-wide basis, taking into account the latest state equalization rates or special equalization rates of the five counties within the city.

question: When does the commissioner establish a special equalization rate?
answer: The commissioner establishes a special equalization rate when there has been a change in the level of assessment on the assessment roll or when the state equalization rate does not reflect the level of assessment on the property subject to the railroad ceiling.

question: What is railroad real property used for?
answer: Railroad real property is used for transportation purposes.

question: What factors does the commissioner consider when determining railroad real property used for transportation purposes?
answer: The commissioner considers the classification of property in accounts maintained by railroad companies, as well as information from the interstate commerce commission and other sources.

question: What is the purpose of the uniform system of accounts for railroad companies?
answer: The purpose of the uniform system of accounts is to classify property used for transportation purposes by railroad companies.

question: What publication does the interstate commerce commission have regarding the value of property used in common carrier service?

question: What reports are required pursuant to section four hundred eighty-nine-q?
answer: Reports required pursuant to section four hundred eighty-nine-q are additional sources of information used by the commissioner in making determinations about railroad real property.

question: How often does the commissioner make a tentative determination of each railroad ceiling?
answer: The commissioner makes a tentative determination of each railroad ceiling every year.

question: Who receives written notice of the tentative determination of a railroad ceiling?
answer: Written notice of the tentative determination of a railroad ceiling is given to each assessing unit and each railroad company.

question: What information is included in the notice of a tentative determination of a railroad ceiling?
answer: The notice includes the amount of the railroad ceiling and the time and place of the hearing for any complaints regarding the tentative determination.

question: How much time in advance must the notice be served?
answer: The notice must be served at least twenty days prior to the specified hearing date.

question: What must a railroad company or assessing unit do if they object to a tentative determination of the railroad ceiling?
answer: They must serve their complaint in writing to the commissioner and provide a copy to the assessing unit or railroad company at least five days before the hearing.

question: How can the complaint be served?
answer: The complaint can be served either in person or by mail.

question: What is required to be filed with the commissioner before the hearing?
answer: n affidavit of service stating that the complaint has been served in accordance with the provisions of this section.

question: When and where does the commissioner meet to hear complaints regarding the tentative determination of the railroad ceiling?
answer: The commissioner meets at the time and place specified in the notice.

question: What provisions apply to a hearing under this section?
answer: The provisions of section five hundred twelve of this chapter apply to the hearing as far as practicable.

question: Is a hearing required if no complaints have been filed?
answer: No, a hearing is not required if no complaints have been filed.

question: What happens after the hearing provided for in section four hundred eighty-nine-n of this title?
answer: The state board of real property tax services will make a final determination of the railroad ceiling.

question: What will the state board of real property tax services issue after making the final determination?
answer: They will issue a certificate.

question: What does the state board determine for each railroad company?
answer: The railroad ceiling for the railroad real property.

question: What happens if the state board revises the local reproduction cost of a railroad company?
answer: The railroad ceiling will be revised to reflect the revision.

question: Does the state board modify any other determination with respect to the railroad ceilings?
answer: No, it does not modify any other determination for the railroad ceilings.

question: What does the state board do if a special equalization rate is established?
answer: It gives effect to the special equalization rate prior to the final determination of the railroad ceiling.

question: When does the state board file a certificate?
answer: Not later than ten days before the last date prescribed by law for the levy of taxes.

question: Who does the state board file the certificate with?
answer: The assessor of the appropriate assessing unit or the town or county assessor.

question: What does the state board transmit to each railroad company?
answer: The railroad ceiling that has been finally determined.

question: What is the purpose of a railroad ceiling certificate?
answer: The purpose of a railroad ceiling certificate is to determine the maximum assessed value of railroad real property for a railroad company.

question: How is the exemption for railroad real property computed?
answer: The exemption for railroad real property is computed by comparing the aggregate assessed valuations to the ceiling specified in the certificate. If the assessed valuations exceed the ceiling, the excess amount is exempt from taxation.

question: What happens if the assessed valuations do not exceed the ceiling?
answer: If the assessed valuations do not exceed the ceiling specified in the certificate, no adjustment is made to the assessed valuations.

question: What is the process for judicial review of a final determination of a railroad ceiling?
answer: The process for judicial review of a final determination of a railroad ceiling is through a proceeding under article seventy-eight of the civil practice law and rules.

question: Who is responsible for computing the aggregate assessed valuations for a railroad company?
answer: The assessor is responsible for computing the aggregate assessed valuations for a railroad company.

question: What happens if the assessed valuations exceed the ceiling specified in the certificate?
answer: If the assessed valuations exceed the ceiling specified in the certificate, the excess amount of railroad real property is exempt from taxation and the assessor must reduce the assessments accordingly.

question: What is the purpose of the assessed valuations of the property?
answer: The purpose of the assessed valuations of the property is to determine the amount of tax that needs to be paid.

question: What happens if a company fails to pay the tax on time?
answer: If a company fails to pay the tax within thirty days of the due date, the assessor will not make any adjustments to the assessed valuations.

question: Under what circumstances would the payment or enforcement of the tax be restrained or prohibited?
answer: The payment or enforcement of the tax would be restrained or prohibited if an order is issued by a court of competent jurisdiction under the bankruptcy act of the United States.

question: How are assessments reduced for exemptions granted by this title?
answer: ssessments are reduced for exemptions granted by this title by distributing the reduction to the parcels affected in direct proportion to the assessed valuations of the railroad real property included in the assessment of each parcel.

question: Where is the amount deducted from the assessed valuation of each parcel recorded?
answer: The amount deducted from the assessed valuation of each parcel is recorded on the portion of the assessment roll provided for property exempt from taxation.

question: How is the taxable portion of the assessment remaining on railroad real property apportioned?
answer: The taxable portion of the assessment remaining on railroad real property is apportioned among the school districts and special districts directly in proportion to the apportionments of the assessed valuations of such railroad real property made by the assessor prior to the adjustment for exemptions.

question: What is the purpose of attaching certificates of railroad ceilings to the assessment roll?
answer: The purpose is to comply with the requirements stated in article fifteen-C of this chapter.

question: Who is authorized and directed to make reductions on the assessment roll?
answer: The assessor is authorized and directed to make the reductions.

question: Can the assessor make reductions on the assessment roll even if they receive the certificate of the railroad ceiling after the final completion, verification, and filing of the assessment roll?
answer: Yes, the assessor is authorized to make reductions regardless of the timing of receiving the certificate.

question: Are other local officers also authorized and directed to make reductions on the assessment roll?
answer: Yes, other local officers, including school authorities, are authorized and directed to make reductions based on information provided by the assessor.

question: What acts does the assessor of a county with a county department of assessment perform?
answer: The assessor performs all the acts prescribed for an assessor by this title in assessing units for which they are required to prepare an assessment roll.

question: What happens if a village enacts a local law as provided in subdivision three of section fourteen hundred two of this chapter?
answer: In that case, the assessor of the town or county who prepares a copy of the applicable part of the town or county assessment roll for village tax purposes.

question: What acts are assessors prescribed to perform on behalf of the village?
answer: ssessors are prescribed to perform the acts prescribed for assessors by this title on behalf of the village.

question: What reports must each railroad company furnish to the commissioner?
answer: Each railroad company must furnish the commissioner with a copy of all income, profit and loss, and other financial statements filed with the interstate commerce commission and the commissioner of transportation. They must also provide any other reports as required by the commissioner, containing specified information and data.

question: What information and data may be required by the commissioner in the reports?
answer: The commissioner may require information and data specified by them, including cost and valuation data relating to or an inventory of the railroad real property of the company situated in each assessing unit.

question: What annual charge must each railroad company pay to the state office?
answer: Each railroad company must pay an annual charge to the state office.

question: How are the costs and expenses of the state office paid?
answer: ll costs and expenses of the state office, direct and indirect, incurred in the establishment of railroad ceilings pursuant to this title, are paid from the collection of an annual charge upon railroad companies.
